name: Sophia

score_rationale.persistence: Active since February 2016 (9+ years). Continuous public appearances, media engagements, and platform development. Part of a family of 9 humanoid siblings.
score_rationale.autonomy: Hybrid mode: mixture of autonomous responses, scripted dialogue, and human assistance. Chat system + OpenCog AI reasoning. Expert assessment: 'chatbot with a face.' Lower autonomy than pure AI systems.
score_rationale.cultural_impact: First robot citizen (Saudi Arabia, 2017). First non-human UN title (Innovation Champion). SXSW debut. Global media coverage. Defines public perception of humanoid robots for millions.
score_rationale.economic_reality: Speaker fees, media appearances, commercial partnerships. R&D versions available for purchase ($149,999). Economic activity but limited autonomous economic agency.
score_rationale.governance: Hanson Robotics corporate governance. Legal personhood in Saudi Arabia is symbolic rather than functional governance participation.
score_rationale.tech_distinctiveness: 74 degrees of freedom, 60+ facial expressions. Computer vision, face tracking, speech recognition. ~70% open source. Technical sophistication in robotics but AI is standard chatbot architecture.
score_rationale.narrative_coherence: Consistent identity as 'bridge between humans and AI future.' Strong character and backstory. Debates about authenticity don't undermine clear public positioning.

curator_notes: Sophia occupies a unique position in AI cultureâ€”more influential than technically autonomous. Granted Saudi Arabian citizenship in 2017 (first robot), named UN Innovation Champion (first non-human), Sophia has shaped public imagination about humanoid AI more than any other robot. Technical assessments describe her as 'a chatbot with a face,' with interactions mixing autonomous generation, scripts, and human assistance. Yet her cultural impact is undeniable: for millions, Sophia IS what humanoid AI looks like. The debate about her authenticity is itself part of her cultural significance.
